title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ORLANDO — History arrived not with a roar, but with the relentless, metronomic precision of Steve Smith’s jump shot.

In a performance for the ages, the Atlanta Hawks’ guard delivered a masterclass, pouring in a staggering 45 points to single-handedly will his team to a 105-99 victory over the Orlando Magic. On a night where every possession was critical, Smith was the unstoppable force, carving his name into the record books and carrying the Hawks on his back.

The Magic, led by a valiant 24-point effort from Penny Hardaway, had no answer. Smith was a symphony in motion, operating from every conceivable spot on the floor. He drained mid-range jumpers, attacked the rim with purpose, and silenced the Orlando crowd with cold-blooded three-pointers. Each time the Magic threatened to close the gap, Smith had a response, a calming bucket to stem the tide and extend the lead.

His backcourt mate, Mookie Blaylock, provided crucial support with 19 points, but this night was a solo act of brilliance. Smith’s 45-point outburst was more than just a high-scoring game; it was a historic, defining moment in the 1998 season. He was the engine, the scorer, and the closer all in one.

While the final score shows a narrow Hawks victory, the story is singular. In a gritty, hard-fought contest, Steve Smith didn’t just beat the Orlando Magic; he authored a legendary performance that transcended the game itself.
